0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Bleeding - Fibrinogen deficiency, Congenital: baseline fibrinogen level known, dose = (target level (mg/dL) - measured level (mg/dL)) divided by 1.7 (mg/dL per mg/kg body weight) IV
  • Bleeding - Fibrinogen deficiency, Congenital: baseline fibrinogen level unknown, 70 mg/kg IV
  • Bleeding - Fibrinogen deficiency, Congenital: maintain fibrinogen level of 100 mg/dL until hemostasis is obtained

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Bleeding - Fibrinogen deficiency, Congenital: baseline fibrinogen level known, dose = (target level (mg/dL) - measured level (mg/dL)) divided by 1.7 (mg/dL per mg/kg body weight) IV
  • Bleeding - Fibrinogen deficiency, Congenital: baseline fibrinogen level unknown, 70 mg/kg IV
  • Bleeding - Fibrinogen deficiency, Congenital: maintain fibrinogen level of 100 mg/dL until hemostasis is obtained

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe immediate hypersensitivity reactions to human fibrinogen, or any component of the product, including immediate, life-threatening anaphylaxis reactions

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity reactions (eg hives, tightness of chest, wheezing, hypotension and anaphylaxis) may occur during or after injection; discontinue immediately
  • patients with risk factors for thrombosis; thrombosis has been reported
  • human plasma derivative; infectious agent risk, including viruses and theoretical risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Neurologic:Headache (greater than 1%)
  • Other:Fever (greater than 1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Myocardial infarction
  • Hematologic:Arterial thrombosis, Deep venous thrombosis, Thromboembolic disorder
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Fibrinogen (coagulation factor I) is a soluble plasma glycoprotein and a physiological substrate of 3 enzymes: thrombin, factor XIIIa, and plasmin. Thrombin converts fibrinogen into fibrin. Fibrin is stabilized in the presence of calcium ions and by activated Factor XIII. Factor XIIIa induces cross-linking of fibrin polymers which result in the fibrin clot being more elastic and more resistant to fibrinolysis. The cross-linked fibrin is the end result of the coagulation cascade.

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• 16 years of age and older: 78.7 hr
  • less than 16 years of age: 69.9 hr

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute with 50 mL Sterile Water for Injection; gently swirl but do not shake vial
  • reconstituted fibrinogen is stable for 24 hours at 20 to 25 degrees C
  • administer through a separate injection site and do not mix with other medications or solutions
  • administer within 24 hours of reconstitution by slow intravenous injection at a rate not exceeding 5 mL/min

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• fibrinogen level, with a target level of 100 mg/dL maintained until hemostasis is achieved
  • decreased bleeding and adequate hemostasis
  • white blood cell count to screen for potential infections
  • early signs of allergic or hypersensitivity reactions and discontinue therapy if necessary
  • signs and symptoms of thrombosis which may occur with therapy
  • signs and symptoms of infection, including hepatitis

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a remote risk of transmitting infectious agents. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare professional.
  • This drug may cause anaphylaxis, fever, and headache.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of thrombosis (pulmonary, myocardial, DVT).
